stories.title: The Great Chillán Earthquake
stories.description: On January 24, 1939, a devastating 8.3 magnitude earthquake shook the Ñuble region, with Chillán being one of the most affected cities.
stories.content:
The 1939 Chillán earthquake was one of the most destructive earthquakes in Chilean history. It occurred at 11:32 PM on January 24, 1939, with a magnitude of 8.3 on the Richter scale.

The city of Chillán was almost completely destroyed. It is estimated that around 28,000 people died throughout the affected region, making it one of the deadliest natural disasters in the country's history.

After the tragedy, the city was rebuilt with new anti-seismic standards and a modern urban design for the time. The reconstruction was led by architects and urban planners who implemented innovative construction techniques.

This event led to the creation of the Reconstruction and Relief Corporation (CORFO), an institution that played a fundamental role in Chile's economic development during the 20th century.
stories.author: Regional Historical Archive

stories.title: San Bartolomé Cathedral
stories.description: Chillán Cathedral, built after the 1939 earthquake, is a symbol of reconstruction and faith of the Chillán community.
stories.content:
Chillán Cathedral, officially known as San Bartolomé Cathedral, was built between 1941 and 1961 as part of the city's reconstruction after the 1939 earthquake.

Designed by architect Hernán Larraín Errázuriz, the cathedral features a modern architectural style with neo-Gothic influences. Its construction used advanced anti-seismic techniques for the time.

The cathedral stands out for its colorful stained glass windows that narrate the religious history of the region and for its 42-meter-high bell tower, which became a symbol of the rebuilt city.

Inside, it houses valuable religious artworks, including sculptures and paintings that were donated by the community during the reconstruction process.
stories.author: Architectural Heritage

stories.title: The San Carlos Longaniza Tradition
stories.description: San Carlos is famous throughout Chile for its traditional longaniza, a sausage that is a fundamental part of local gastronomy.
stories.content:
San Carlos longaniza is one of the most emblematic gastronomic products of the Ñuble region. Its tradition dates back to the early 20th century, when Spanish immigrants arrived in the area bringing with them sausage-making techniques.

San Carlos longaniza is characterized by its unique flavor, the result of a traditional recipe that has been passed down from generation to generation. It is made mainly with pork, seasoned with paprika, cumin, garlic and other secret spices.

The production process is completely artisanal. The meat is finely ground, mixed with spices and stuffed into natural casings. It is then hung to dry in ventilated places.

San Carlos longaniza has transcended regional borders and has become a nationally recognized product.
stories.author: Culinary Traditions

stories.title: Nevados de Chillán
stories.description: The Nevados de Chillán volcanic complex is one of the region's most important tourist destinations, famous for its hot springs and ski centers.
stories.content:
Nevados de Chillán forms an active volcanic complex located in the Andes mountain range, on the border between the Ñuble and Biobío regions. This mountain system includes several volcanoes, the highest being Volcán Chillán at 3,212 meters high.

The area is famous for its natural hot springs, known since pre-Columbian times for their medicinal properties. Chillán hot springs have become an important thermal tourism and wellness center.

During winter, the Nevados transforms into one of the most important ski centers in central-southern Chile. The slopes offer different difficulty levels and a snow season that extends from June to September.

The area's biodiversity is exceptional, harboring endemic species of Andean flora and fauna, including the Andean condor and various species of native orchids.
stories.author: Ñuble Tourism

stories.title: Quinchamalí Black Pottery
stories.description: The pottery tradition of Quinchamalí represents one of Chile's oldest and most recognized artisanal expressions.
stories.content:
Quinchamalí black pottery is an artisanal tradition that dates back to pre-Columbian times. This unique technique, transmitted from generation to generation, mainly by women, has made this small town a national reference for traditional pottery.

The production process is completely manual and requires great skill. Local clay is used and molded without a wheel, only with hands. The pieces are dried in the sun and then fired in open-air clay ovens.

The characteristic black color is obtained through a special firing technique in which the pottery is covered with leaves and branches, creating a reducing atmosphere that produces the distinctive glossy black finish.

The most traditional pieces include jugs, pots, plates and decorative figures. Each piece is unique and reflects the creativity and skill of its creator.
stories.author: Cultural Heritage

stories.title: Itata Valley and its Heritage Wines
stories.description: The Itata Valley is considered the cradle of Chilean viticulture, with traditions dating back to the 16th century.
stories.content:
The Itata Valley has the honor of being Chile's oldest wine region. The first vineyards were planted by Spanish conquistadors in the 16th century, making this area the cradle of national viticulture.

The valley's unique climatic conditions, with dry summers and rainy winters, along with granitic and volcanic soils, create an exceptional terroir for growing heritage grape varieties like País and Moscatel.

Itata's winemaking tradition is characterized by ancestral cultivation and winemaking methods. Many vineyards still use dry farming techniques, without artificial irrigation, which concentrates flavors and produces wines of unique character.

In recent years, the valley has experienced a renaissance, with new producers combining tradition and innovation to create wines that express the unique identity of this historic territory.
stories.author: Regional Enology

stories.title: The Battle of Yungay
stories.description: On January 20, 1839, in the fields of Yungay, one of the most decisive battles of the War against the Peru-Bolivian Confederation was fought.
stories.content:
The Battle of Yungay, fought on January 20, 1839, marked the end of the War against the Peru-Bolivian Confederation and consolidated Chile's independence. This decisive battle took place in the fields near the town of Yungay.

The Restoring Army, commanded by Manuel Bulnes, faced the Confederation forces led by Andrés de Santa Cruz. The Chilean victory was overwhelming and meant the end of confederate ambitions in the region.

The Chilean military strategy, which included an enveloping maneuver and effective use of artillery, demonstrated the tactical superiority of the national army. The battle lasted approximately two hours and resulted in the complete defeat of the confederate forces.

Today, the Yungay Battlefield is a national historic site where the memory of this fundamental episode in Chilean history is preserved.
stories.author: Military History

stories.title: Salto del Laja
stories.description: One of Chile's most spectacular waterfalls, Salto del Laja is a natural phenomenon that has captivated visitors for centuries.
stories.content:
Salto del Laja is an impressive waterfall formed by the Laja River as it plunges from a height of approximately 35 meters. This natural wonder is located in the commune that bears its name and constitutes one of the region's most important tourist attractions.

The waterfall is formed when the Laja River, which originates in the lake of the same name in the Andes mountain range, encounters a volcanic rock formation that creates this spectacular water fall. The surrounding landscape is dominated by basaltic formations dating from prehistoric volcanic eruptions.

The Salto del Laja area has been inhabited since pre-Columbian times. Indigenous peoples considered this place sacred and attributed special spiritual properties to it.

Today, Salto del Laja is a popular tourist destination that offers trails, viewpoints and picnic areas, allowing visitors to enjoy this natural wonder up close.
stories.author: Natural Geography

stories.title: Bulnes Railway Station
stories.description: The historic Bulnes railway station was a key point in the development of transportation and connectivity in the Ñuble region.
stories.content:
Bulnes Railway Station, inaugurated in 1875, was part of the ambitious project to connect Santiago with southern Chile through the railroad. This station became a nerve center for passenger and freight transport in the region.

The construction of the railroad completely transformed the local economy. Bulnes became an important center for collection and distribution of agricultural products, especially wheat, which was transported to ports for export.

The station's architecture reflects the typical railway style of the era, with wood and iron structures that combined functionality and elegance. The main building housed administrative offices, waiting room and the station master's residence.

Although passenger service was suspended in the 1990s, the station remains an important symbol of Chilean railway history and a testament to the role of trains in regional development.
stories.author: Railway Heritage

stories.title: Native Forests of Ñuble National Reserve
stories.description: Ñuble National Reserve protects one of the most important forest ecosystems in central-southern Chile.
stories.content:
Ñuble National Reserve, created in 2009, protects 56,000 hectares of native forest in the Andes mountain range. This protected area harbors exceptional biodiversity and represents one of the last refuges for endemic species in the region.

The reserve's forests are dominated by native species such as oak, raulí, coigüe and araucaria. These ecosystems provide habitat for diverse fauna including pumas, pudús, condors and a great variety of endemic birds.

The reserve plays a fundamental role in conserving the region's watersheds, protecting the headwaters of important rivers and ensuring water supply for local communities.

The reserve's trails offer visitors the opportunity to experience the pristine beauty of Chilean native forest and observe species that have inhabited these territories for millennia.
stories.author: CONAF Ñuble
